# üéØ Inferential Statistics

Inferential statistics let us make conclusions about a population based on sample data. This includes concepts like probability, sampling distribution, confidence intervals, and hypothesis testing. These methods help determine whether observed patterns are statistically significant or could have happened by chance.

### 2. What does a p-value represent in hypothesis testing?

<label><input type="radio" name="q2" value="a"> A. The probability the null hypothesis is true</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="q2" value="b"> B. The probability of obtaining results at least as extreme as those observed, assuming the null hypothesis is true</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="q2" value="c"> C. The level of confidence in the data</label><br>

<br>

### 3. A 95% confidence interval means...

<label><input type="radio" name="q3" value="a"> A. We are 95% confident the population parameter lies within the interval</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="q3" value="b"> B. 95% of the data falls in this range</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="q3" value="c"> C. There's a 95% chance the sample mean is accurate</label><br>

<br>

### 4. What does the Central Limit Theorem say?

<label><input type="radio" name="q4" value="a"> A. Large samples are always more accurate</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="q4" value="b"> B. Sampling distributions of the mean tend to be normal if the sample size is large enough</label><br>
<label><input type="radio" name="q4" value="c"> C. All distributions are normally shaped</label><br>

<br>

<script>
function gradeQuiz() {
  const answers = {
    q1: "c",
    q2: "b",
    q3: "a",
    q4: "b",
    q5: "b"
  };

  let score = 0;
  let total = 5;

  document.querySelectorAll("form label").forEach(label => {
    label.style.color = "";
  });

  for (let q in answers) {
    const selected = document.querySelector(`input[name="${q}"]:checked`);
    if (selected) {
      const label = selected.parentElement;
      if (selected.value === answers[q]) {
        label.style.color = "green";
        score += 1;
      } else {
        label.style.color = "red";
      }
    }
  }

  const percent = Math.round((score / total) * 100);
  document.getElementById("score").innerHTML = `Your Score: ${score}/${total} (${percent}%)`;
  document.getElementById("feedback").innerHTML = (score >= 3)
    ? "‚úÖ Good job! You may proceed."
    : "‚ùå Try again before moving to the next section.";
}
</script>
